acsefunctions API Documentation¶

This module contains all the functions used in this project

acsefunctions.bessel_j(alpha, x, N=20)[source]¶

Compute the Bessel function J_alpha(x) using a truncated series expansion. Supports scalar and vector inputs.

Parameters:

  • alpha (float) – The order of the Bessel function.

  • x (float or array-like) – point(s) to evaluate the Bessel function.

  • N (int) – The number of terms in the series expansion (default is 20).

Returns:

The approximate value of J_alpha(x).

Return type:

float or ndarray

Examples: >>> bessel_j(0, 1)

0.7651976865579666

>>> bessel_j(1, [0, 1, 2])
        array([0.        , 0.44005059, 0.57672481])
acsefunctions.cosh(x, N=20)[source]¶

Approximate cosh(x) using the Taylor series expansion.

Parameters:

  • x (float or array-like) – The point(s) at which to evaluate cosh(x).

  • N (int) – Number of terms in the Taylor series.

Returns:

The approximation of cosh(x).

Return type:

float or ndarray

Examples: >>> taylor_cosh(1)

1.5430806348152437

>>> taylor_cosh([0, 1, 2])
        array([1.        , 1.54308063, 3.76219569])
acsefunctions.exp(x, N=20)[source]¶

Approximate e^x using the Taylor series expansion.

Parameters:

  • x (float or array-like) – The point(s) at which to evaluate e^x.

  • N (int) – Number of terms in the Taylor series.

Returns:

The approximation of e^x.

Return type:

float or ndarray

Examples: >>> taylor_exp(1)

2.7182815255731922

>>> taylor_exp([0, 1, 2])
        array([1.0, 2.71828153, 7.3890561 ])
acsefunctions.factorial(n)[source]¶

Compute the factorial of a non-negative integer n. Supports scalar and vector inputs.

Parameters:

n (int or array-like) – The number(s) to compute the factorial of.

Returns:

The factorial of n.

Return type:

int or ndarray

Examples: >>> factorial(5)

120

>>> factorial([0, 1, 2, 3])
        array([ 1,  1,  2,  6])
acsefunctions.gamma_function(num)[source]¶

Compute gamma function Γ(z) using recursive calculation and Stirling’s approximation.

Parameters:

z (float or array-like) – The input(s) to the gamma function (z > 0).

Returns:

The approximate value(s) of Γ(z).

Return type:

float or ndarray

Examples: >>> gamma_function(5) 24.0 >>> gamma_function([0.5, 1.5, 5]) array([1.77245385, 0.88622693, 24.])

Raises:

  • ValueError – If z <= 0.

  • OverflowError – If z > 171.5.

  • NotImplementedError – If z is not an integer or half-integer.

acsefunctions.gamma_recursive(num)[source]¶

Recursive calculation for gamma function for integers and half-integers.

Parameters:

num (float) – The input value (integer or half-integer).

Returns:

The gamma function value for the input.

Return type:

float

acsefunctions.sinh(x, N=100)[source]¶

Approximate sinh(x) using the Taylor series expansion.

Parameters:

  • x (float or array-like) – The point(s) at which to evaluate sinh(x).

  • N (int) – Number of terms in the Taylor series.

Returns:

The approximation of sinh(x).

Return type:

float or ndarray

Examples: >>> sinh(1)

1.175201177598364

>>> sinh([0, 1, 2])
        array([0.0, 1.17520118, 3.62686041])
acsefunctions.stirling_approximation(z)[source]¶

Stirling’s approx for gamma function; non-integer, non-half-integer values.

Parameters:

z (float) – The input value for approximation.

Returns:

Approximate value of gamma function using Stirling’s approx.

Return type:

float

acsefunctions.tanh(x, N=20)[source]¶

Approximate tanh(x) as the ratio of sinh(x) to cosh(x).

Parameters:

  • x (float or array-like) – The point(s) at which to evaluate tanh(x).

  • N (int) – Number of terms in the Taylor series.

Returns:

The approximation of tanh(x).

Return type:

float or ndarray

Examples: >>> taylor_tanh(1)

0.7615941559557649

>>> taylor_tanh([0, 1, 2])
        array([0.        , 0.76159416, 0.96402758])
